DESCRIPTION: The nine principle are unique Aspects that embody the archetypal characteristics, ideas, or influences that underpin the entirety of the invisible arts. Power can be drawn from the veneration of a Principle[You may elevate your own Principle to the same intensity as the card’s tier.]
Lantern is the principle of the secret place sometimes called the House of the Sun, and of the light above it.
The principle of the Forge transforms and destroys.
Edge is the principle of battle and of struggle.
Winter is the principle of silence, of endings, and of those things that are not quite dead.[Characters take damage equal to the number of this principle they have at the end of turn.]
The Heart is the principle that continues and preserves.
The principle of the Grail honours both the birth and the feast.
Moth is the wild and perilous principle of chaos and yearning.[It stacks instead of taking maximum,but returns to zero at the end of your turn]
The Knock is the principle that opens doors and unseams barriers.
Secret Histories describe the unknown complexities of the world, and its many pasts.[It stacks instead of taking maximum,you get additional rewards based on this principle you have at checkout.]
Beneath the skin of the world we find the Mansus, also called the World-Spine, also called the House of the Sun.[Cannot be removed, return to hand after played, will be upgraded when resting.]

Knowledge of the invisible arts. I can use it to attract followers, to perform rites, to open the way to the Mansus, to seek my ascension...[Having two Lore cards of same level and principle in your deck will automaticaly merge into one upgraded Lore card.]
An echo, a resonance, an alignment. Something that will fade soon.
A sword does not kill; it is an instrument in the hand of the killer.
Fuel, ointment, pigment, patience: all are consumed in time.
Student, helpmeet, defender, champion, dupe, sacrifice... companion.
A figure of note in the circles where I move.
The laws of civilization are younger than the Laws of the Hours, but they, too, sometimes require a sacrifice.
'The proper things, in the proper manner, in the proper order. God help us all.'
This one is not from here.
I've learned the path to the Wood, tangled darkness that grows around the walls of the Mansus (though the Mansus has no walls).
I've passed the white door, which has been called the Bone Door and the Gate of Ivory. My voice remains outside the House each time I enter.
I've found the way to the Stag Door, sometimes called the Horn Gate or the Adept's Door. I have answered its riddle, and am counted among the Know.
I've found the way to the Spider's Door, sometimes called the Bloody Gate or, more informally, the Wrong Door.
The Peacock Door: proud and shining amethyst, its glow tinting the snow-pale shapes of the Glassgarden. This is the highest point where mortals may penetrate the Mansus.
Exhaust 2 knock and two types of principle to summon a spirit: Stronger spirits requires higher level of principle.
20% damage reduction
Apply 1 Weak or 1 Vulnerable or -1 Strength  。
A card is randomly drawn from the card pool to add to the hand. While levitating, preview the drawn cards.
A card is randomly drawn from the card pool to add to the hand. When hovering, preview the card pool.

Does not include oneself NL Heart: NL 0.1% NL T3 Boss: NL 2.3% NL T2 Boss: NL 2.3% NL T1 Boss: NL 2.3% NL T3 Elite: NL 3.5% NL T2 Elite: NL 4.6% NL T1 Elite: NL 4.8% NL T3 Normal: NL 14.1% NL T2 Normal: NL 23.1% NL T1 Normal: NL 42.9%
